Issues.Title: .columns exceeds width of the page in a .hero-foot and adds whitespace at bottom of page
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.0
My **browser** is: Chrome 83 (MacOS)
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

Placing a .columns element (with two columns) inside a .hero-foot element will cause the .columns element's width to exceed that of the display, which in turn causes the rest of the page to "squash", particularly on smaller devices.

### Steps to Reproduce

I've made a JSFiddle here: https://jsfiddle.net/qe4rpksw/

Although it's perhaps easier to see the problem in a full page since JSFiddle seems to have the bottom of the page cropped off for some reason, in which case one can just copy over the HTML to a local document.

### Expected behavior

The .columns element should be the same width as the rest of the page, for example the .hero-foot. There should be no whitespace underneath the .hero-foot.

### Actual behavior

The .columns element is wider than the page (it appears to be always by 24px). This also causes display issues on mobile because when the page gets shrunk down to accommodate this larger-than-the-screen element it squashes the .hero-foot element. There's also some whitespace underneath the .hero-foot.

![Screenshot 2020-06-29 at 15 51 17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52198062/86021477-05aafb00-ba21-11ea-80f5-7cb3d86a2b8b.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".columns exceeds width of the page in a .hero-foot and adds whitespace at bottom of page" (#3023)

Issues.Title: Default tablet breakpoints don't affect iPads
Issues.Body:
This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** 


### Description

Bulma's default tablet breakpoints do not work with iPads or iPad minis.

From the [docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/overview/responsiveness/), `tablet` refers to devices from 769px to 1023px in width. The trouble is — iPads and iPad Minis are 768px width in portrait, and 1024px width in landscape.

The breakpoint variables can be adjusted, but it seems odd to have defaults that don't work.

This issue was raised 3 years ago [here](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/1420), but the issue was closed.

### Steps to Reproduce

Use any tablet-specific responsive helper on an iPad or iPad mini, and it doesn't work.

Ex. `is-hidden-tablet-only`, `is-two-thirds-tablet`

[Here's a demo](https://bulmatablet--eri-b.repl.co/)

### Expected behavior

iPad or iPad Mini should respond to default Bulma responsive tablet helpers in both Portrait and Landscape mode.

### Actual behavior

iPad Portrait responds to Mobile helper, and iPad Landscape responds to Desktop helper.

<!-- What actually happened -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Default tablet breakpoints don't affect iPads" (#3019)

Issues.Title: Bulma for web components
Issues.Body:
I've been using bulma for styling web components. It's a good fit because it's css only and component-ized, and easy to customize via sass variables. One area that's a problem sometimes is the use of parent/child selectors (">") and that can cause some challenges, esp. with components like navbar, where I'd like to divide up the css into components like nav-bar, nav-bar-item etc. The shadowDOM boundary, and the extra tag introduced by the host element trip things up.

Any suggestions? It would be great if future versions could keep this in mind and maybe think of ways the components themselves might be divided up by web components.

Anyhow, nice framework!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bulma for web components" (#3018)

Issues.Title: Remove height auto from img (Fixes #342)
Issues.Body: This is a **bugfix** that solves the `img` tag problem from issue #342. The main problem is that the following html code doesn't work as expected. ```html ``` The expected is that the image would have 80px of height, but in order to get this behaviour it must be provided the height in CSS form. ```html ``` Which is not always convenient for instance when dealing with user provided html. This problem was caused by the following css style `img {height: auto;}`. ### Proposed solution It is just matter of removing the `height: auto` from `img` tag in: * `sass/base/minireset.sass` * `sass/base/generic.sass` ### Tradeoffs There is no alternative to this (removing the `height: auto` css), see this from StackOverflow: [remove height auto using css](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44010645/remove-height-auto-using-css). Since `height: auto` means its height will be as minimum as possible to fit its children, which in this case is the image, this is already the standard behaviour. After this changes the `img` height will start obeying the `height` attribute when there is not CSS for `height`. ### Testing Done **Current behaviour** ![](https://i.imgur.com/mlh0EdX.png) **After changes:** ![](https://i.imgur.com/NDt9eqI.png) ### Changelog updated? No.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove height auto from img (Fixes #342)" (#3015)

Issues.Body:

### Overview of the problem
This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**

### Description
Hello, we are considering migrating our project ([iTop](https://github.com/Combodo/iTop)) from Bootstrap to Bulma as it seems to be an awesome framework.

We are importing Bulma's .sass files in our own .scss files, which are then compiled using the SCSSPHP library. The problem is that our tools handle SCSS well but not SASS at all.

Issues.Title: Add missed Mixins to docs. Add default values for existing mixins
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **the Docs**.

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

<!-- This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** -->
This is about the Bulma **Docs**

### Description

Current [`Mixins` page](https://bulma.io/documentation/overview/mixins/) ([raw file](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/4ccca9f7d45e4db58090783fef2c44c27488e0cb/docs/documentation/overview/mixins.html)) contain some incorrect mixins and another mixins are missed:

1. `=center($size)` → `=center($width, $height: 0)`
2. `=from($device)` (is missed in docs)
3. `=until($device)` (is missed)
4. `=block` → `=block($spacing: $block-spacing)`
5. `=arrow($color)` → `=arrow($color: transparent)`.

It also better to update all mixins to have the same stule. For example, `=overlay($offset: 0)` contains default value, but `=arrow($color)` does not (default is `transparent`)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2240404/84821925-94347b00-b024-11ea-8fb0-e023955d5f7e.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add missed Mixins to docs. Add default values for existing mixins" (#3002)

Having the ability to push down the footer for short content pages has been requested by many. This pull request is referencing issue #2367.

The solution adds an optional class for footer-parents to push the footer down by growing the second-last section to fill the remaining space.

Without this improvement:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53540163/84566182-87d3c800-ad6f-11ea-81cd-adc396723212.png)

With this improvement:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53540163/84566185-9326f380-ad6f-11ea-9661-92cc2593bb4b.png)

<!-- If it fixes a particular Issue, add "Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER" in your title -->

### Tradeoffs

As this is optional, there are no drawbacks by simply not using this class. The drawback _when_ using the class, is that at the moment only sections are working as the element to be growed.

None.
